item.title: Week 5 - Freq. table and Stem plot
Week 5 - Normal distribution 1
Week 4(STAT:1010) - Describe what you have in your data
Week 4 - Write your own function and Data manipulation
Week 3(STAT:1010) - Data type and errors
item.description: Problem 1 (Data types) Definitions: Qualitative data: values that can be placed into nonnumerical categories. Nominal level of measurement - No ranking! Ordianl level of measurement - It has ranking system! Quantitative data: values representing counts or measurments Countinuous data takes any value in a given interval. Discrete data can take on only particular, distinct values and not other values in between.

item.title: Week 3 - Data visualization 2
item.description: Data loading again # load data mydata <- read.csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/issactoast/EnBlog/master/static/files/stat2010/examscore.csv", header = TRUE) # clean data; choose 1~5 columns as data set mydata <- mydata[,1:5] # check the result head(mydata) ## class std_id midterm1 midterm2 final ## 1 1 1 70 51 67 ## 2 1 2 78 66 66 ## 3 1 3 80 71 67 ## 4 1 4 75 67 70 ## 5 1 5 73 56 81 ## 6 1 6 89 60 69 If you success to load R file, you can see the above results.

item.title: Week 2 - Data visualization
item.description: Data loading again mydata <- read.csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/issactoast/EnBlog/master/static/files/stat2010/examscore.csv", header = TRUE) head(mydata) ## class std_id midterm1 midterm2 final X X.1 ## 1 1 1 70 51 67 NA 1 ## 2 1 2 78 66 66 NA NA ## 3 1 3 80 71 67 NA NA ## 4 1 4 75 67 70 NA NA ## 5 1 5 73 56 81 NA NA ## 6 1 6 89 60 69 NA NA If you success to load R file, you can see the above results.

item.title: Week 1 - R Basics and Data loading
item.description: Basic R code and Data loading Today we will learn about the basic R codes and how to load data file to R. R Basics R can be your fancy calculator. 2 + 1 3 - 2 2 * 3 4 / 2 4^2 sqrt(4) # 4^0.5 9 %% 4 # mod 9 %/% 4 # value We can assign value to a variable using <-. a <- 4 a b <- 2 b b <- 3 b a+b Variable contains not only a number but also many things.

item.title: Statistical Methods and Computing (STAT:2010 or 4200)
item.description: Welcome to my discussion section for STAT:2010 and STAT:4200. Issac (Sak) Lee Office location: 213 SH Office hour: Friday 2pm - 5pm Email: sak-lee@uiowa.edu Please put a tag STAT:2010 or STAT:4200 in front of your title when you email me. Course materials Week 0: Access to the virtual desktop Week 1: Basic R and data loading Week 2: Data visualization Week 3: Data visualization 2 (in progress)

item.title: Statistics and Society (STAT:1010)
item.description: Welcome to my discussion section for STAT:1010. Issac (Sak) Lee Office location: 213 SH Office hour: Friday 2pm - 5pm Email: sak-lee@uiowa.edu Please put a tag STAT:1010 in front of your title when you email me. Attendance policy We have 13 weeks for this semester. You will get 3 free absences. Thus, your attendance will counts as 1 point and you will get 10 points in total from this discussion section.

item.title: Week 0: Preparation
item.description: Access to the virtual desktop To access the software R and SAS, we can use virtual desktop which the University of Iowa provide students for free. You can think virtual desktop as remote computer which you can log-in through the website. Click the link below. U of Iowa virtual desktop If you are first time to use this website, you need to download the Citrix Workspace App and install it.

item.title: Week 2(STAT:1010)
item.description: Problem 1 A large warehouse is flled with light bulbs. An electronics engineer wants to estimate the mean lifespan of these bulbs. To this end, 18 of the bulbs were randomly selected and the lifespan was measures; the mean lifespan of the 18 bulbs was 2550 hours. What is the population? What is the sample? What is the parameter? What is the sample statistics? Problem 2 In a survey of 400 randomly selected UI students, 30% of students said they like a chocolate ice cream.

item.title: Academic: the website designer for Hugo
item.description:
Academic is a framework to help you create a beautiful website quickly. Perfect for personal sites, blogs, or business/project sites. Check out the latest demo of what you’ll get in less than 10 minutes. Then head on over to the Quick Start guide or take a look at the Release Notes.
Key features: Easily manage various content including homepage, blog posts, publications, talks, and projects Extensible via color themes and widgets/plugins Write in Markdown for easy formatting and code highlighting, with LaTeX for mathematical expressions Social/academic network linking, Google Analytics, and Disqus comments Responsive and mobile friendly Simple and refreshing one page design Multilingual and easy to customize Color Themes Academic is available in different color themes and font themes.
